jeopardy_round: TO EVERYTHING THIS IS A SEASON

(1, 1).clue: 1808:Napoleon's brother Joseph is made king of this neighbor of France

(2, 1).clue: (Leonard Maltin reads the clue.) 1935's "The Band Concert", my favorite animated short, featured the color debut of this ultimate Disney icon, who played the maestro

(3, 1).clue: Introduced in 2001, Pibb Xtra is a bolder version of this similarly named beverage

(5, 1).clue: Munich's 16-day (or so) annual beer festival staggers to an end in this season

(6, 1).clue: Like a loon's, a tern's feet have this feature, yet terns are not notable swimmers

(1, 2).clue: 1708:Later a state capital, this city is incorporated & renamed for Princess Anne of England

(2, 2).clue: (Leonard Maltin reads the clue.)  The craze inspired by this TV hero in the '50s took Walt by surprise; he'd killed him off at the Alamo in episode 3, so he had to film prequels in order to bring him back

(3, 2).clue: Quite simply, Bubble Up is "a kiss of lemon, kiss of" this

(4, 2).clue: An ugly old witch who always wants to be "it"

(5, 2).clue: The annual Earth Day celebration takes place during this season

(6, 2).clue: The sooty tern is about 16 inches long with a white forehead & is otherwise this color above & white below

(2, 3).clue: (Leonard Maltin reads the clue.)  The crown jewel of Walt's career was this, my favorite Disney film of all time--& it gave the world a new movie star, Julie Andrews

(3, 3).clue: Aargh!  Black lemonade must be perfect for pirates; this Jolly Roger symbol adorns its label

(4, 3).clue: A mumblety-peg tool for a spouse
(4, 3).correct response: a wife knife (a knife wife accepted)

(5, 3).clue: Pamplona's running of the bulls zips by during this season

(6, 3).clue: This geographic tern's 20,000-mile trip gives it the longest migration of any bird

(1, 4).clue: 1608:Dutchman Hans Lippershey files for a patent for this new scientific instrument

(2, 4).clue: (Leonard Maltin reads the clue.)  A chance meeting with Leopold Stokowski led Walt to hire him for a "Sorcerer's Apprentice" short; Stokowski prodded him into making a longer film, this 1940 epic

(3, 4).clue: The drink known as "Code" this is "everything you love about Mountain Dew with a smooth cherry flavor"

(4, 4).clue: A push from a pugilist's padded paw

(5, 4).clue: We don't think Mike Tyson celebrates Boxing Day, which falls in this season, but he's surprised us before

(6, 4).clue: Terns eat insects, small fish & this type of arthropod whose name comes from the Latin for "hard-shelled ones"

(1, 5).clue: 508:Clovis I establishes this city as the capital of the Merovingian kingdom

(2, 5).clue: (Leonard Maltin wraps it up.)  My favorite animated Disney film is this 1941 classic in which a lovable misfit becomes a high-flying circus star

(3, 5).clue: Made originally from the roots of Smilax plants & similar to root beer, this sassy Old West treat is still served today

(4, 5).clue: NHL projectile in a violent frenzy

(5, 5).clue: Louisiana celebrates Battle of New Orleans day during this season, y'all

(6, 5).clue: Named for the "sea" between SE Europe & Asia, this 21-inch-long bird is one of the largest kinds of tern
(6, 5).correct response: the Caspian tern (the Caspain Sea accepted)

(1, 1).clue: When this prince dies, Horatio prays that "flights of angels sing thee to thy rest"

(3, 1).clue: Female deep-sea anglerfish use this, produced by bacteria, to attract prey

(4, 1).clue: In 1990 Iraq invaded & tried to absorb this much smaller country it called its "19th province"

(5, 1).clue: On old TV, "A fiery horse" & "a cloud of dust" let you know this guy was either coming or going

(6, 1).clue: Breakfast dish that can also mean "to flatten"

(1, 2).clue: In "The Merchant of Venice", he says, "Since I am a dog beware my fangs"

(3, 2).clue: Using adsorption (yes, with a "d"), activated charcoal in these military items attracts harmful chemical vapors

(4, 2).clue: It's the nearest capital city to the peak of Mount Everest

(5, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew runs a wet finger around the rims of two crystal glasses with different amounts of water in them.) The more water in the glass, the slower these are, & the deeper the tone

(6, 2).clue: In 1966 the U.S. government banned M-80s & these round, red firecrackers

(1, 3).clue: A nurse tells Juliet, "His name is Romeo, and a" member of this family, "the only son of your great enemy"

(2, 3).clue: Cobie Smulders,Josh Radnor,Bob Saget (well, his voice, anyway)

(3, 3).clue: In a covalent bond, 2 atoms each contribute one of these to a pair, which is then attracted to the atoms' nuclei

(4, 3).clue: It became a Caribbean capital in 1872

(5, 3).clue: On a building site, you're a brick layer, but a pipe one of these

(6, 3).clue: The Boeing P-26 fighter of the 1930s & '40s was nicknamed this, like a classroom weapon

(1, 4).clue: This play ends with, "goodnight unto you all.  Give me your hands, if we be friends, and Robin shall restore amends"

(3, 4).clue: Bombykol, one of these attractant chemicals, is sort of the Calvin Klein obsession of the female silk moth

(4, 4).clue: This capital city lies on the shores of Lake Victoria

(5, 4).clue: A cold-causing agent, its name combines the Greek & Latin words for "nose poison"

(6, 4).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew ties one on.)  It's the 2-word spicy name for this type of knot that lets you join a rope to something else, like a rail or a post

(1, 5).clue: When Mistress Page receives a love letter from Falstaff in this play, she asks, "How shall I be revenged on him?"

(3, 5).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew is a bit too on-the-nose.)  Gravity, the shape of a spoon, & this molecular force of attraction between separate bodies, from the Latin for "to stick", help me do an amazing trick

(4, 5).clue: This second-most populous Afghan city is said to have been founded by Alexander the Great

(5, 5).clue: Jesus was a teenager when this Roman was banished for a poem on the art of making love

(6, 5).clue: Reference to this container suggests the homespun style & philosophy of rural folk

(0, 0).clue: This state has the largest sand dunes complex in the U.S., just north of a river named for its flatness
